desc: PAX5 encodes a transcription factor involved in B-cell development. Translocations of PAX5 are found in lymphomas and leukemias.

PAX5 is a protein in the paired-box family of transcription factors that is important in early B-cell development and differentiation (PMID:10524622). PAX5 plays a key role in the commitment of bone marrow multipotent progenitors to the B-lymphoid lineage by favoring VDJ gene rearrangement and activating the expression of B-cellâ€“specific genes (PMID: 9442394) while simultaneously repressing genes involved in other hematopoietic differentiation programs (PMID: 12479824). PAX5 mutations, translocations, and deletions are found in B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemias (ALL) (PMID: 17344859, 8943844). A germline susceptibility mutation in PAX5 for development of B-cell ALL has also been identified (PMID: 24013638).
articles/0/title: A recurrent germline PAX5 mutation confers susceptibility to pre-B cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
articles/1/title: Pax5 promotes B lymphopoiesis and blocks T cell development by repressing Notch1.
articles/2/title: Genome-wide analysis of genetic alterations in acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.
articles/3/title: The t(9;14)(p13;q32) chromosomal translocation associated with lymphoplasmacytoid lymphoma involves the PAX-5 gene.
articles/4/title: Essential functions of Pax-5 (BSAP) in pro-B cell development.
articles/5/title: Commitment to the B-lymphoid lineage depends on the transcription factor Pax5.
